overview_summary: None of these four neighbors have made a clear public statement about local development or clean energy, leaving their stances classified as unknown. All appear to have relatively limited public roles; we found no evidence of high-profile community leadership among them. Influence is therefore assessed as low across the group, with no neighbor holding formal office or significant sway in local governance.

neighbors.name: Bill D. Gaiche
neighbors.claims: Bill D. Gaiche is a resident of Chouteau in Mayes County, noted for participating in a regional fishing tournament in 1999 [Major League Fishing](https://majorleaguefishing.com/anglers/bill-gaiche-101602/). No record was found of Gaiche taking part in local government meetings or public debates on development as of the latest available information (i.e., he has not been cited in news or county minutes by name).

approach_recommendations.engage: Have a local outdoors enthusiast or conservation representative reach out to discuss how the project can preserve the quiet, natural environment he enjoys. Emphasize habitat protection and minimal disruption to fishing and wildlife.

neighbors.name: Lyndsi Hellard & Devon Looney
neighbors.claims: Lyndsi Hellard is listed as the Director of Operations at a property development firm based in Beverly Hills, California [SignalHire](https://www.signalhire.com/profiles/lyndsi-hellard's-email/130719613), suggesting she may not reside locally full-time. Devon Looney (co-owner of the parcel with Hellard) has no notable public profile in Mayes County; neither individual appears in local news or civic records concerning development issues.

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage via a professional channel — for example, a project development liaison — emphasizing how the proposal could enhance their land’s value and bring economic benefits. Since Hellard has a real estate background, use data-driven points about property and tax advantages.

neighbors.name: Vernon L. & Sandra Harrell
neighbors.claims: Vernon L. Harrell (approximately 71 years old) and his wife Sandra are long-time Mayes County residents, currently living near Chouteau, OK [BestHistorySites](https://besthistorysites.net/name/vernon-harrell). Public records show Vernon Harrell has resided at a rural Chouteau address since at least 2005 ([besthistorysites.net](https://besthistorysites.net/name/vernon-harrell#:~:text=match%20at%20L433%20229%20Pryor,current%20address)). The Harrells have not been identified in any news reports or public meetings related to local development, indicating a low public profile.

approach_recommendations.engage: Have a respected local farmer or agricultural extension agent approach them to discuss how the project will protect farmland and maintain the peace of the countryside. Emphasize commitments to preserving their way of life and minimizing disturbance.

neighbors.name: Teresa & Michael Carnes
neighbors.claims: Michael and Teresa Carnes are landowners in rural Mayes County; their mailing address has been linked with the Rose/Locust Grove vicinity of the county ([truepeoplesearch.net](https://truepeoplesearch.net/people/teresa-carnes#:~:text=match%20at%20L323%20,9803%20%2A%20AND%202%20MORE)). They keep a low public profile – no mentions of the Carnes family were found in local media or public records regarding development or community issues. Their engagement with community organizations appears minimal or non-public.

approach_recommendations.engage: Reach out through a neighborly connection or local farm bureau representative to address practical concerns. Discuss how the project will include proper land stewardship – for example, protecting soil quality and managing road use – aligning with their interest in preserving their farmland.
